Award.AwardTitle: Equivariance and Higher Algebra in Motivic Homotopy Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
Algebraic geometry is concerned with understanding solutions of polynomial equations. It has long been known that in general one cannot hope to find exact solutions to polynomial equations, even for a single equation in one variable. Nevertheless, it is often possible to answer more qualitative questions about the set of solutions. In particular, one of the most fundamental and notoriously difficult questions in algebraic geometry is whether solutions exist at all. Motivic homotopy theory is a relatively new approach to such questions, and it has already helped solve many open problems in the past twenty years. It borrows many ideas and techniques from a different field of mathematics, topology, and successfully applies them to algebraic geometry in unexpected ways. Following this trend, this project aims to bring several fruitful ideas from topology to the world of algebraic geometry.

This project consists of two parts. In the first part, the PI will develop equivariant motivic homotopy theory from the point of view of parametrized homotopy theory. In the second part, the PI will study highly structured commutative algebras in motivic homotopy theory and hopes to address the problem of recognizing motivic loop spaces. More specifically, the PI will lay solid foundations for equivariant motivic homotopy theory by constructing Grothendieck's six-functor formalism for fiberwise homotopy theory over algebraic stacks. The mere existence of this formalism has interesting consequences for classical invariants of stacks, like algebraic K-theory; it can also be used to construct new well-behaved cohomological invariants of algebraic stacks, and to better understand the relations between them. In the second part of this project, the PI will introduce a motivic refinement of the notion of E_infinity ring and show that many classical cohomological invariants of algebraic varieties possess this refined multiplicative structure. The PI will also introduce the related notion of motivic E_infinity space and investigate their role in a potential recognition principle for infinite motivic loop spaces. To achieve these goals, the PI will use existing as well as new methods from equivariant algebraic geometry, ordinary motivic homotopy theory, classical algebraic topology, and higher category theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
1. Project goals

In the proposal, I outlined two separate research projects in the field of motivic homotopy theory. The goal of the first project was to develop equivariant motivic homotopy theory. More specifically, I planned to:

(1) lay solid foundations for equivariant motivic homotopy theory by constructing Grothendieck's six-functor formalism for fiberwise homotopy theory over algebraic stacks;
(2) gather the consequences of this formalism for classical invariants of stacks, like algebraic K-theory, and use it to construct new cohomological invariants of algebraic stacks.

The goal of the second project was to study commutative algebras in motivic homotopy theory. I planned to:

(3) introduce a motivic refinement of the notion of E-infinity-ring and show that many classical cohomological invariants of algebraic varieties possess this refined multiplicative structure;
(4) study the related notion of motivic E-infinity-space and investigate their role in a potential recognition principle for infinite P1-loop spaces.

2. Results

All of the project goals were successfully achieved:

(1) I developed the formalism of six functors in equivariant motivic homotopy theory in [10].
(2) As applications, I proved cdh descent for equivariant homotopy K-theory in [9]. With Amalendu Krishna in [12], we used this to prove general vanishing results for the negative K-theory of tame Deligne-Mumford stacks.
(3) The notion of "motivic E-infinity-ring", now officially called normed motivic spectrum, was developed in joint work with Tom Bachmann [3]. In this work we show in particular that most of the usual motivic cohomology theories are represented by normed motivic spectra, and that this structure gives rise to power operations generalizing Voevodsky's power operations in motivic cohomology.
(4) The notion of "motivic E-infinity-space", now officially called framed motivic space, was developed in joint work with Elden Elmanto, Adeel Khan, Vladimir Sosnilo, and Maria Yakerson [7]. In particular completely resolve the question of recognizing infinite P1-loop spaces. This theory proved to be very powerful and came with interesting connections. For example, it turns out to be closely related to the theory of virtual fundamental classes. The papers [11, 5, 6] explore these connections and further applications.

This project also generated several fruitful collaborations: with Amalendu Krishna on vanishing results for negative equivariant K-theory, with Tom Bachmann on motivic E-infinity-rings, and with Elden Elmanto, Adeel Khan, Vladimir Sosnilo, and Maria Yakerson on the recognition principle for infinite P1-loop spaces. The latter two, in particular, have opened new avenues of research in motivic homotopy theory that continue to be investigated and applied by various authors. To name some examples, the work of Gepner and Heller on motivic tom Dieck splitting in equivariant motivic homotopy theory [8], the work of Bachmann, Elmanto, and Heller on power operations for motivic spectra [1], the work of Bachmann and Hahn on motivic nilpotence [2], and the work of Bachmann and Yakerson on the Gm-stabilization conjecture [4]. Overall, the results of this project have had a major impact on the field of motivic homotopy theory as a whole.

[1] Tom Bachmann, Elden Elmanto, and Jeremiah Heller. Mod 2 power operations in normed motivic spectra. 2019.
[2] Tom Bachmann and Jeremy Hahn. Nilpotence in normed MGL-modules. 2019.
[3] Tom Bachmann and Marc Hoyois. Norms in motivic homotopy theory. 2018.
[4] Tom Bachmann and Maria Yakerson. Towards conservativity of Gm-stabilization. 2018.
[5] Elden Elmanto, Marc Hoyois, Adeel A. Khan, Vladimir Sosnilo, and Maria Yakerson. Framed transfers and motivic fundamental classes. to appear in J. Topol., 2019.
[6] Elden Elmanto, Marc Hoyois, Adeel A. Khan, Vladimir Sosnilo, and Maria Yakerson. Modules over algebraic cobordism. 2019.
[7] Elden Elmanto, Marc Hoyois, Adeel A. Khan, Vladimir Sosnilo, and Maria Yakerson. Motivic infinite loop spaces. 2019.
[8] David Gepner and Jeremiah Heller. The tom Dieck splitting theorem in equivariant motivic homotopy theory.2019.
[9] Marc Hoyois. Cdh descent in equivariant homotopy K-theory. 2017.
[10] Marc Hoyois. The six operations in equivariant motivic homotopy theory. Adv. Math., 305:197-279, 2017.
[11] Marc Hoyois. The localization theorem for framed motivic spaces. 2018.
[12] Marc Hoyois and Amalendu Krishna. Vanishing theorems for the negative K-theory of stacks. to appear in Ann. K-Theory, 2018.
